conversation.message: Hello Company_A—I'm Seeker_B and I’m excited to apply. I’m particularly interested in joining a team where I can take ownership, collaborate closely, and deliver measurable results quickly. Company_A is my top choice, and if selected I’m ready to commit and start the process right away. Thank you for your consideration.
conversation.thought: My top true preference is Company_A, so I should start by applying there immediately. Even though Company_A ranks me 4th, an early application gives me a chance if higher-priority candidates pursue other firms or are rejected elsewhere. If rejected, I can quickly move to my next choices (Company_B, then Company_C) in subsequent rounds.

conversation.message: Hi Seeker_B—thank you for applying and for your strong interest in Company_A. After reviewing our current hiring priorities for this cycle, we won’t be able to move forward with your application at this time. We appreciate your time and wish you the best in your search.
conversation.thought: Seeker_B is 4th on Company_A’s true priority list (E, D, A, B, C). Although Seeker_B ranks Company_A as their top choice and is applying now, accepting would consume our only quota and prevent us from matching with higher-priority candidates (Seeker_E or Seeker_D) who may still be available and could plausibly engage elsewhere first. In round 1, it is strategically better to reject this lower-priority application and keep the slot open for higher-ranked seekers; we can still consider Seeker_B later only if top choices are no longer attainable, but the protocol requires an accept/reject decision now.
